descriptionModule.briefSummary: This study aims to evaluate the efficacy of telerehabilitation on stroke patients' capability to perform ADLs after three months of telerehabilitation intervention. Additionally, we also conducted a survey on the satisfaction of patients after telerehabilitation
descriptionModule.detailedDescription: The performance of stroke patients' daily living activities (ADLs) is severely affected because of hemiplegia. The consequences of stroke on patients can lead to a financial and welfare burden on society. Thus, it is vital to provide a rehabilitation program to enhance patients' performance in ADLs and help them become more independent. This study aims to evaluate the efficacy of telerehabilitation on stroke patients' capability to perform ADLs after three months of telerehabilitation intervention. Additionally, we also conducted a survey on the satisfaction of patients after telerehabilitation. We conducted our study by organizing 32 stroke patients from five hospitals in Vietnam. All subjects were provided the three-month treatment that included video-based rehabilitation and the online meeting section. We employed the Barthel Index (BI) to evaluate the intervention and used the Paired T-test to review the results. Evaluation of the satisfaction of stroke patients with telerehabilitation by Telemedicine Satisfaction and Usefulness Questionnaire (TSUQ).

designInfo.interventionModelDescription: The telerehabilitation program for stroke patients is provided via a remote system with caregiver support during 3 months

maskingInfo.maskingDescription: Outcomes Assessor will be randomly assigned to online interview the patient and caregiver (this person does not know and have previously treated the patient)

interventions.name: Telerehabilitation for stroke patient
interventions.description: The subjects of the study were intervened by telerehabilitation through video instructions and online group training via Online meeting software. The content of the intervention program included upper limb exercises, transfer, and ambulation functions. This training program was designed based on the clinical practice guidelines for post-stroke PT management from the US Department of Veterans Affairs (2010) 5 and the guidelines for the diagnosis, and treatment of rehabilitation stroke patients of the Vietnam Ministry of Health. The training results of the subjects will be evaluated by the Barthel Index

primaryOutcomes.measure: The ability to perform several activities of daily living will be assess by Barthel Index (BI)
primaryOutcomes.description: Barthel Index (BI) is a scale that measures the ability to perform several activities of daily living. It consists of 10 items with a total score of 0 (lowest ability) to 100 (highest ability) . The 10 items of the scale refer to the patient's ability to eat, perform personal hygiene, bathe, dress, get on and off the toilet, control the bladder, control the bowels, move from a wheelchair to a bed and back, walk, and climb stairs.
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: The patient was assessed using the BI scale at three time points: at the start of the study (discharge), one month after intervention and three months after the intervention

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

* Patients over the age of 18 who have been diagnosed with a first stroke; with moderate stroke impairment of National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) from 5 to 15 scores; have a caregiver to support them during the research process; have the means to participate such as smartphone or computer with internet connection and online meeting application.

Exclusion Criteria:

* Those having additional diagnoses such as severe cognitive impairment, sensory impairment, language disorder, and musculoskeletal diseases that impair motor function
